dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, is American politics just a massive, you know, theatrical production now? Like, seriously?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, is American politics just a massive, you know, theatrical production now? Like, seriously?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, yes, exactly! It's like, indistinguishable from entertainment, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, yes, exactly! It's like, indistinguishable from entertainment, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But in the United States, politics has long been indistinguishable from entertainment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Like, Mencken called it "the greatest show on earth" back in, what, 1927? But it's even more so now, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Like, Mencken called it the greatest show on earth back in, what, nineteen twenty seven? But it's even more so now, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The caustic American journalist H.L. Mencken, who despised politicians and thought most Americans were ignorant oafs, was a great observer of political party conventions. He wrote in 1927: The United States, to my eye, is incomparably the greatest show on earth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely! All the glitz, the speeches, the tears, the balloons, even, like, the carefully chosen outfits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely! All the glitz, the speeches, the tears, the balloons, even, like, the carefully chosen outfits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It had everything: glitzy musical acts, rousing speeches, religious devotion, floods of tears, promises of hope, moments of joy, uplifting patriotism, Oprah Winfrey, and lots and lots of balloons. Television commentators marveled at the way Vice President Kamala Harris presented herself: her smile, her body language, her voice, even her choice of clothing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! The wardrobe committees! For the First Lady and the VP. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! The wardrobe committees! For the First Lady and the V P. It's wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's all about, uh, showmanship, you know? And that sentimental gush, the hugging the family on stage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's all about, uh, showmanship, you know? And that sentimental gush, the hugging the family on stage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Politics, whether in dictatorships or democracies, always involves showmanship of one kind or another. ... But the sentimental gush of US party conventions the hugging, the kissing, and the effusions of familial love is conspicuous in other American ceremonial occasions, too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But why? Like, why do they have to make such a show of loving their families? Is it even necessary?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But why? Like, why do they have to make such a show of loving their families? Is it even necessary?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently, yes! Pew Research found a direct link, like, between public affection and positive polling with undecided voters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently, yes! Pew Research found a direct link, like, between public affection and positive polling with undecided voters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But that's so American, though, isn't it? Other democracies, like, they vote for parties, not, um, not for how warm and fuzzy a person seems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that's so American, though, isn't it? Other democracies, like, they vote for parties, not, um, not for how warm and fuzzy a person seems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In most democracies, people vote for political parties and the interests they represent. ... But overall, Asian and European politicians are not nearly as eager or as willing as Americans to sell themselves to the public as warm and loving human beings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! It's almost, like, royal court behavior, isn't it? Like monarchs used to do to seem accessible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! It's almost, like, royal court behavior, isn't it? Like monarchs used to do to seem accessible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ever since King George III (Farmer George) in the eighteenth century, British monarchs liked to be seen as fine, upstanding family people. Queen Elizabeth II allowed the BBC to document her domestic life, from barbecues in the garden to tea with the children. She felt that she had to come down to earth to remain popular.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And we rebelled against kings! But then we want our presidents to be "regular guys" while also, you know, putting on this massive display.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And we rebelled against kings! But then we want our presidents to be regular guys while also, you know, putting on this massive display.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans liberated themselves from the British monarchy in 1776 (Farmer George was their last king). In the intervening years, the White House has acquired much of the pomp and circumstance of a royal court... To ascend to the US presidency, with all its quasi-monarchical trappings, a candidate like the British royals must make a great show of being a regular guy or gal, a person like you and me, someone to have a beer with on the front porch.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's like the Oscars, too, right? American stars thanking everyone, crying, compared to, uh, crisp foreign acceptance speeches.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like the Oscars, too, right? American stars thanking everyone, crying, compared to, uh, crisp foreign acceptance speeches.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Foreign recipients of an Oscar, for example, tend to keep acceptance speeches crisp and short. Not the American stars, who must tearfully thank everyone from their primary schoolteachers to their pet dogs, and express their deep devotion to humanity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! It's this performance of authenticity. Like, they're supposed to be genuine but they're literally performing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! It's this performance of authenticity. Like, they're supposed to be genuine but they're literally performing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What we see, then, at the party convention and the Oscar ceremony, in the television interview and the magazine profile, is the performance of authenticity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! They're performers, but we crave them to be authentic. It's, like, the greatest show on earth for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! They're performers, but we crave them to be authentic. It's, like, the greatest show on earth for sure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They are performers. To put on an act is, by definition, to create something that is not real. And yet the public demands from actors and politicians that they come across as genuine. ... In the right hands, as was the case in Chicago, this can indeed look like the greatest show on earth.
